a. Presents with severe bleeding
b. Sex-linked recessive disease
c. Due to defects in LMAN1 and MCFD2 genes
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
The Leyden phenotype of hemophilia B is characterized by:
a. Severe hemophilia A in childhood that becomes mild after puberty
b. Mild hemophilia A in childhood that becomes severe after puberty
c. Severe hemophilia B in childhood that becomes mild after puberty
d. Severe hemophilia A and B in childhood that become mild after
puberty
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
The incidence of hemophilia A is:
a. 1 in 5000 live male births
b. 1 in 10000 live male births
c. 1 in 15000 live male births
d. 1 in 20000 live male births
Answers: Ans. a.

Questions:
The cause of decreased risk of bleeding in severe hemophilia A may
be:
a. Factor V Leiden,
b. Protein C deficiency, the
c. Prothrombin G20210A gene variant
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
The inhibitors develop in.. of patients with severe hemophilia A:
a. 5 percent
b. 15 percent
c. 25 percent
d. 35 percent
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
Symptomatic hemophilia A can develop in females because of:
a. X-chromosome inactivation resulting in low levels of factor VIII.
b. Mating between an affected male and a carrier female producing
homozygous disease
c. Loss of an X-chromosome in Turner syndrome
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Obligate carrier in hemophilia is defined as:
a. Mother of more than one hemophilic son
b. Daughter of a patient with hemophilia
c. All of the above
d. None of the above
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
Patients with high responder inhibitors have:
a. Increase in antibody titer after each exposure
b. Response begins within 2 to 3 days,
c. Peaks at 7 to 21 days, and
d. May persist for years in the absence of reexposure
e. All of the above
Answers: Ans. e.

Questions:
Inhibitor development is least common with:
a. Large deletions  38 percent
b. Nonsense mutations  36 percent
c. Inversions  20 percent
d. Small deletions  14 percent
e. Missense mutations  7 percent
Answers: Ans. e.

Questions:
According to the CANAL study, one of the following is not a risk factor
for inhibitor development:
a. Family history of inhibitors
b. High-risk gene mutation present
c. Intensive treatment at first episode
d. Starting treatment with factor at early age
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Antibodies are most commonly directed against the following
domain in factor VIII inhibitors:
a. A2 domain
b. C2 domain
c. A3 domain
d. C1 domain
Answers: Ans. b.

Questions:
Cryoprecipitate contains  times more factor VIII compared to
fresh frozen plasma:
a. 10
b. 30
c. 50
d. 100
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
IV administration of 0.5 international units/kg of body weight of
factor VIII will increase circulating factor VIII levels by:
a. 0.5 international units/dL
b. 1 international units/dL
c. 1.5 international units/dL
d. 2 international units/dL
Answers: Ans. b.

Questions:
The usual dose of epsilon aminocaproic acid is:
a. 25 to 50 mg/kg per dose every six hours
b. 50 to 75 mg/kg per dose every six hours
c. 75 to 100 mg/kg per dose every six hours
d. 100 to 125 mg/kg per dose every six hours
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
Patients with factor IX inhibitors have:
a. Increased risk of nephrotic syndrome
b. Increased risk of anaphylaxis
c. Poor response to immune tolerance induction
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
What percent of patients with hemophilia A do not have a family
history of bleeding?
a. 10%
b. 20%
c. 30%
d. 40%
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
How many patients of hemophilia A have severe disease?
a. 1020%
b. 2030%
c. 3040%
d. 5060%
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
The following is not the feature of Fanconi anemia:
a. Short stature
b. Hypopigmented spots and caf-au-lait spots
c. Abnormality of thumbs
d. Macrocephaly
e. Hypogonadism
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
The most common malignancy in Fanconi anemia is:
a. Acute myeloid leukemia
b. Squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck
c. Genitourinary malignancy
d. Skin cancers
Answers: Ans. b.

Questions:
Peak age of presentation of Fanconi anemia is:
a. Less than 1 year
b. 15 years
c. 515 years
d. 1520 years
e. More than 20 years
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
Triad of dyskeratosis congenita include, all except:
a. Anemia
b. Hyperpigmented rash
c. Nail dystrophy
d. Mucosal leukoplakia
Answers: Ans. a.

Questions:
Dyskeratosis congenita is inherited as:
a. X-linked recessive trait
b. Autosomal dominant trait
c. Autosomal recessive trait
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Treatment of choice for dyskeratosis congenita is:
a. Androgens
b. Growth factors
c. Androgens, growth factors and supportive care
d. Stem cell transplantation
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
True about Shwachman-Diamond syndrome are, except:
a. Usually presents in infancy
b. Endocrine pancreatic insufficiency c. Bone marrow failure
d. Skeletal anomalies
Answers: Ans. b.

Questions:
True about Shwachman-Diamond syndrome are:
a. Conversion mutations which recombine portions of the pseudogene
and SBDS gene, resulting in a dysfunctional SBDS gene
b. Autosomal recessive disorder
c. It is a ribosomopathy
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Bone marrow involvement in chronic lymphocytic leukemia is:
a. Stage 0
b. Stage 1
c. Stage 3
d. Stage 4
Answers: Ans. a.

Questions:
Stage of most common presentation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia
is:
a. Stage 0 (lymphocytosis)  25 percent
b. Stages I to II (lymphadenopathy, organomegaly)  50 percent
c. Stages III to IV (anemia, thrombocytopenia)  25 percent
d. All stage have equal frequency of presentation
Answers: Ans. b.

Questions:
The median survival from the time of diagnosis in stage 3 and 4
chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients is:
a. 10 months
b. 20 months
c. 30 months
d. 40 months
Answers: Ans. b.

Questions:
Autoimmune phenomena seen in chronic lymphocytic leukemia
are, all except:
a. Coombs' positive autoimmune hemolytic anemia
b. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura
c. Pure red cell aplasia
d. Rheumatoid arthritis
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Cytogenetic abnormalities seen in chronic lymphocytic leukemia
are all except:
a. Trisomy 12
b. 14q+
c. del 13q14
d. 11p deletion
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Indications for treatment in chronic lymphocytic leukemia are all
except:
a. Symptomatic anemia and/or thrombocytopenia
b. Repeated episodes of infection
c. Severe insect hypersensitivity
d. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia and/or thrombocytopenia that are
poorly responsive to corticosteroid therapy
e. del 17p
Answers: Ans. e.

Questions:
Adverse prognostic features in chronic lymphocytic leukemia are,
except:
a. ZAP-70
b. CD38
c. Unmutated immunoglobulin Vh genes
d. del 13q14
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Treatment of choice for patients with localized (stage I) SLL is:
a. Observation
b. Localized radiation therapy
c. Chemotherapy
d. Chemotherapy plus localized radiation therapy
Answers: Ans. b.

Questions:
Patients with del(17p) or del(11q) are at high risk because of:
a. Not responding adequately to initial treatment
b. Relapsing soon after achieving remission
c. Requiring treatment early
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Regarding alemtuzumab therapy in chronic lymphocytic leukemia,
all are true, except:
a. Single agent alemtuzumab results in overall response and complete
remission (CR) rates of approximately 83 and 24 percent, respectively.
b. A survival benefit has not been demonstrated
c. Effective when maximum lymph nodes < 5 cm in diameter
d. Can deplete bone marrow leukemic clone and achieve MRD
negativity
e. All are true
Answers: Ans. e.

Questions:
Which of the following drug is not used in chronic lymphocytic
leukemia?
a. Mitoxantrone
b. Pentostatin
c. Fludarabine
d. All are used
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Alemtuzumab is effective in CLL with chromosome 17p deletion
because it:
a. Acts through IP3/mTOR pathway
b. Acts through heat shock proteins
c. Acts through p53 pathway of apoptosis
d. Bypasses p53 pathway of apoptosis
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
AML has been associated with:
a. Trisomy 21
b. Fanconi's anemia
c. Bloom's syndrome
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
The minimum number of blasts required for diagnosis of AML with
t(8;21)(q22;q22) are:
a. 10%
b. 20%
c. 30%
d. None of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Good risk acute myeloid leukemia include, all except:
a. t(8;21)(q22;q22)
b. inv(16)(p13.1q22)
c. APL with t(15;17)(q22;q12) with DIC
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
AML with t(8;21)(q22;q22) is associated with:
a. CEFB-MYH11
b. RUNX1-RUNX1T1
c. MLLT3-MLL
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. b.

Questions:
WHO classification of AML include the following major categories
except:
a. AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities
b. AML with myelodysplasia-related features
c. Replased and refractory AML
d. Therapy-related AML
e. AML, not otherwise specified
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
True about AML with t(8;21)(q22;q22) are:
a. Blasts with long thin Auer rods
b. Presence of c-KIT mutations is an adverse prognostic feature
c. Patients can have transcripts of the RUNX1-RUNX1T1 detected by
RT-PCR even in patients who have been in remission for many years
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Patients with AML with inv(16)(p13;q22) have:
a. FAB M4Eo phenotype
b. O ccurs in younger patients
c. Can present as an extramedullary myeloid sarcoma
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Which of the following AML has favourable prognosis among these?
a. AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23)
b. AML with t(6;9)(p23;q34)
c. AML with inv(3)
d. AML with del 7q
Answers: Ans. a.

Questions:
True about AML with mutations in FLT3 are all except:
a. Seen in 30 to 40 percent of patients with AML and normal cytogenetics
b. O ften present with high WBC counts
c. The presence of a FLT3 mutation can overcome the favorable effects
of NPM1 and CEBPA mutations
d. High dose cytarabine is the preferred treatment
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
True about AML with minimal differentiation is:
a. There are no cytoplasmic granules or Auer rods and
b. They cannot be differentiated from ALL based upon morphology
c. The blasts are negative for the myeloperoxidase (MPO) or sudan
black B (SBB) reactions
d. Most cases express CD15 and CD65
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
AML without maturation has the following features, except:
a. At least 20 percent of the blasts stain for MPO and/or SBB (3% NOT
20%)
b. Many cases express antigens of early hematopoiesis (e.g. CD34, CD38,
HLA-DR)
c. They express one or more myeloid-associated antigens (e.g. CD13,
CD33, CD117)
d. Markers of granulocytic maturation (e.g. CD15, CD65) are not
expressed in most cases.
Answers: Ans. a.

Questions:
The goal of induction chemotherapy is:
a. To rapidly restore normal bone marrow function
b. To decrease the minimal residual disease
c. To prevent the relapse
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. a.

Questions:
After achieving remission following induction therapy the number
of blasts left in body are:
a. No blast left b. 103 blasts left
c. 106 blasts left
d. 109 blasts left
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Veno-occlusive syndrome post-transplant includes, all except:
a. Weight gain
b. Ascites
c. Hepatomegaly
d. Decreased urine output
Answers: Ans. b.

Questions:
CSF to evaluate for CNS involvement in AML is recommended for all,
except:
a. Patients with a high white blood cell count (>100,000/microL) at the
time of diagnosis
b. Patients with a monoblastic phenotype
c. CD56 positivity
d. AML M7
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
ECOG 3 performance status is:
a. Fully ambulatory and able to carry out light work
b. Up and about > 50 percent of waking hours
c. Confined to bed > 50 percent of waking hours
d. Completely disabled, totally confined to bed
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
A monosomal karyotype, is:
a. Defined as at least two autosomal monosomies
b. Is a single autosomal monosomy in the presence of one or more
structural cytogenetic abnormalities
c. Is associated with unfavorable risk disease than a complex karyotype
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
True regarding abnormalities in the nucleophosmin (NPM1) gene
in AML are:
a. Found in approximately 50 percent of patients with de novo normal
karyotype AML
b. NPM1 mutations have been associated with improved outcomes in
both adults and children with AML
c. The concurrence of FLT3 mutations negates the positive effect of
NPM1 mutations
d. All of the above
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
False regarding CEBPA gene mutation is:
a. Found in approximately 10 percent of patients with newly diagnosed
AML
b. Longer median overall survival c. Its effect is independent of other high-risk molecular features
d. Prognosis is similar whether patient has two copies of the mutation
or single allele CEBPA mutaton
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Older patients with AML have poor prognosis because:
a. Poorer performance status
b. Higher incidence of multidrug resistance
c. Lower percentage of favorable cytogenetics
d. Lower complete remission rates, shorter remission durations, and
shorter median overall survival
e. All of the above
Answers: Ans. e.

Questions:
Cytogenetic abnormalities that are closely associated with AML and
are not seen in MDS are:
a. Chromosomal deletion
b. Chromosomal gain
c. Chromosomal loss
d. Balanced translocations
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Patients with a good risk MDS can have:
a. Normal karyotypes
b. -Y
c. del(5q)
d. del(20q)
e. All of the above
Answers: Ans. e.

Questions:
The 5q- syndrome is a distinctive type of primary MDS that primarily

a. Median age at diagnosis is 68 years,
b. Female predominance of 7:3
c. Presents with refractory macrocytic anemia and normal or elevated
platelet counts
d. Absence of significant neutropenia
e. All of the above
Answers: Ans. e.

Questions:
RPS14, required for the maturation of 40S ribosomal subunits, is
implicated in the genesis:
a. 5q-syndrome
b. MDS/MPN syndrome
c. MDS with trisomy 8
d. MDS with del 7
e. All of the above
Answers: Ans. a.

Questions:
The following is not true of 5q- syndrome:
a. Lenalidomide is TOC
b. Median survival is 63 months
c. Hypomethylating agents are highly effective
d. Infection and bleeding are unusual

Questions:
Definitive hematopoiesis begins in:

b. Yolk Sac
c. AGM region (Around aorta)
d. Spleen
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
Essential properties of hematopoietic stem cells include, all except:

b. Ability to differentiate
c. Transdifferentiation
d. High proliferative capacity

Which of the following growth factors/cytokines are not of potential

b. Erythropoetin
c. GM-CSF
d. Interleukins

Earliest hemoglobin to appear is:

b. Gower 1

d. HbF

Division occur up to which stage of erythroid development?

Primary granules are seen first in which stage of myeloid development?

b. Myelocyte
c. Band
d. Promyelocyte

Which of the following is the constituent of azeurophillic granules

b. Major basic protein c. MPO
d. Elastase

Basophills are characteristically stained by which cytochemistry?

Germinal center B-cells are characterized by:

b. BCL6

d. CD34

Paracortical areas are most rich in:

c. Plasma cells
d. T-cells

Cortical thymocytes are characterised by:

b. CD 3 positivity

Questions:
The color of Dhole bodies in neutrophil:
a. Blue
b. Voilet
c. Magenta
d. Red

Questions:
All of the following are good prognostic factors in CLL, except:
a. Cd 38 positivity
b. ZAP 70 positivity
c. TLC >1,00,000/cumm
d. Unmutated phenotype

Questions:
Most common cytogenetic abnormality in CLL:
a. de13q14

c. t(9;22)
d. del 11q22

Which of the following explain the lymphocytosis in CLL?

Questions:
monoclonal B-cell lymphocytosis is charecterised by:

b. CLL phenotype

Not a classical feature of CLL immunophenotype:

Prolymphocytic transformation is marked by, all except:

c. Appearance of increased numbers of prolymphocytes in the

Autoantibodies against red cells in CLL are:

b. IgM
c. IgA
d. IgE

Richter Syndrome develops in:

b. CLL
c. HD

Questions:
Not true about CLL:
a. Insect bite hypersensitivity
b. Caused by ionizing radiation
c. Can have AIHA
d. ZAP 70 is surrogate for IGH mutation

Monocytocysis in CML is associated with:

b. p190

Accelerated phase of CML is characterised by, all except:

b. Blast count 1019% in PS or BM

Questions:
Which of the following are recognized complications in essential

a. Acute leukemia
b. Erythromelalgia
c. Thrombosis
d. All of the above

Questions:
The marrow fibrosis is reflected by all peripheral blood findings,

a. Nucleated RBC
b. Presence of immature myeloid cells
c. Microcytic hypochromic blood
d. Tear drop cells

Questions:
Molecular abnormality seen most commonly in Polycythemia vera

a. JAK2 V617F
b. bcr abl
c. MLL gene rearngments
d. CEBPA mutations

Questions:
Parts of the physical examination will be most helpful in ruling out

a. Musculoskeletal
b. Cardiac
c. Respiratory
d. Abdominal

Questions:
CML is associated with, all except:
a. Abnormal chromosome b. High neutrophil alkaline phosphatase

d. Huge spleen

Questions:
Translocation t(9;22) in a primitive hematopoietic stem cell results

JAK2 mutation causes cellular proliferation which is due to a:

d. Stimulation of viral oncogene

Questions:
Which among the following is the most common tumor associated

a. Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia
b. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
c. Acute monocytic leukemia
d. Acute myeloid leukemia

Questions:
Following is a myeloid marker:
a. CD3
b. CD10
c. CD13
d. CD19

Questions:
Most common type of congenital leukemia is:

b. AML
c. CLL
d. CML

Which of the following cytogenetic abnormality is associated with

Block PAS positivity usually seen in:

Questions:
Which is not a poor prognostic factor for ALL?

Questions:
High apoptotic tumor cell death is characteristic of:

Questions:
CNS involvement is more common in:

Questions:
Which of the following is a bad prognostic cytogenetic marker in

Questions:
MDS 5q syndrome is characterised by, all except:

Ans.
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
WHO diagnostic criteria for multiple myeloma includes, all except?

c. Marrow plasma cell > 30%
d. O rgan damage

Questions:
Known case of amyloidosis presents with prolonged PT, aPTT and

a. Acquired factor V deficiency
b. Acquired factor X deficiency
c. Acquired dysfibrinogenemia
d. Acquired hypofibrinogenemia

Questions:
Plasmablasts show positivity for:

b. MPO
c. SBB
d. PAS

Questions:
Which of the following is not true about multiple myeloma?
a. Background staining in PS
b. Rouleax formation
c. Circulating plasmacytoid cells

Questions:
Good prognostic cytogenetic in multiple myeloma:
a. t(11;14)

Questions:
Dutcher bodies are:
a. Intracytoplasmic
b. Intranuclear
c. Intramitochondrial

Questions:
The least common monoclonal Ig (M protein) is:
a. IgG
b. IgA
c. IgM
d. IgD

Questions:
Not true about MGUS:
a. 1% per year transformation to MM
b. Cytogenetic abnormalities different from that seen in MM
c. M protein < 3 gm/dL
d. No disease related symptoms

Questions:
M spike can be seen in all except:
a. Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma
b. Multiple myeloma
c. Mycoisis fungoides
d. CLL

Questions:
A patient is found to have multiple lytic bone lesions with increased

No M spike is seen on serum protein electrophoresis. The next best

a. Serum/urine immunofixation
b. Free light chain assay
c. Plasma cell labelling index
d. Immunohistochemistry
Answers: Ans. a.

Questions:
Following are the features of Hairy Cell Leukemia, except:
a. Splenomegaly
b. Pancytopenia
c. TRAP positivity
d. Leukocytosis

Questions:
B symptoms in Hodgkin disease is defined as:
a. Weight loss more than 10% in 3 months
b. Generalized lymphadenopathy
c. Drenching night sweats
d. Erythroderma

Questions:
Which of the following is not true regarding epidemiology of non-

a. It is more frequent after solid organ transplantation
b. It is associated with hepatitis C infection
c. Incidence is decreasing in Western Europe
d. It may be associated with malaria
Answers: Ans. c.

Questions:
A 60 years old man presents with headache and anemia. Investigation

diagnosis?
a. Burkitt lymphoma
b. Follicular lymphoma
c. Mycosis fungoides
d. Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Which is the single most valuable investigation in diagnosis of non-
Hodgkin lymphoma?
a. CT scan
b. FNAC
c. Flow cytometry
d. Lymph node biopsy
Answers: Ans. d.

Questions:
Which of the following is not associated with development of NHL?
a. H. pylori
b. CMV
